paragraphs.text: The new Sketch file is a hidden ZIP. By renaming .sketch to .zip, you can unpack the file and see all internal files and folders. In fact, you can pack and rename a (Sketch) .zip to .sketch and open it again. Bohemian Coding might set a new (technical) standard for design. The new .sketch is practically a design repository. I do agree though that "repository" might be too technical a word/concept for designers but the .sketch file does act as a development repository. The only difference is that Sketch packs all data in a ZIP.
paragraphs.name: 0ec9

paragraphs.text: The new Sketch file is a hidden ZIP. By renaming .sketch to .zip, you can unpack the file and see all internal files and folders. 79e23e62f234.title: Thanks for the summary and peak into the future.

paragraphs.text: Thanks for the summary and peak into the future. What’s not mentioned here is the ability to finally go cross-platform. Having a JSON/zip format for design will likely lead to windows based GUI editors that can consume .sketch files.
paragraphs.name: dc7e

99f0cfb56520.title: So lets say you use Bootstrap as your base, and you’ve created some customized styles from it.

paragraphs.text: So lets say you use Bootstrap as your base, and you’ve created some customized styles from it. Will you be able to “load” that into Sketch? Now your styles for buttons will show up as Symbols, for example? I’m pretty excited by the possibilities, none the less!
paragraphs.name: 6dd1

af545618898b.title: I really don’t think that the changes introduced to the .sketch

paragraphs.text: I really don’t think that the changes introduced to the .sketch file type mean that you will see ‘design to front-end’ handoff automated any time soon.

paragraphs.text: I do believe it’s a step in the right direction in terms of version control and plugin development (specially for import/export plugins). But for handoff automation I think a…

b3d4bd1b1b73.title: The pinnacle of cool in this area would be if Sketch could open a folder as a project.

paragraphs.text: The pinnacle of cool in this area would be if Sketch could open a folder as a project. This folder would have the same structure as the zip, and could be versioned. Now that would be magic.
paragraphs.name: 17a0

aeaeb41a66f1.title: Could you provide more context around what is meant by “Designers now define the actual UI code”.

paragraphs.text: Could you provide more context around what is meant by “Designers now define the actual UI code”. I see that the sketch files are now scripted but I don’t see how this translates to front-end code.

d756274cdd8a.title: The idea I had in mind is that actual UI components gets translated into actual UI code.

paragraphs.text: The idea I had in mind is that actual UI components gets translated into actual UI code. Somewhat like the plugins Measure or Sympli generate a webpage out of the visual elements in Sketch. I do think that designers have to follow and stick to certain conventions and schema for it to work properly. Though, I might have gone a little overboard with "actual…" actually.
paragraphs.name: 654d

paragraphs.text: Thank you, Ken.

91ee134a83f.title: Webflow is the closest, I would agree.

paragraphs.text: Webflow is the closest, I would agree. The thing though is that most designers, and that is I would say around 80–90%, would not touch webflow to "design" because it requires to have some understanding of frontend development. In fact, with Sketchs move into reusable components it allows a designer to actually stay within their world (read: not…

a94f17e27e5e.title: It seems that at least text layer data is still binary.

paragraphs.text: It seems that at least text layer data is still binary. As suggested by field names, Sketch uses standard binary archivers of certain text related Cocoa objects and encodes binary data produced by these archivers as base64 strings to store in a file. These cannot be correctly merged by version control systems or easily created by hand. Of course…
Very good point, Ali.
paragraphs.name: d4ba

fff31352cbb9.title: This could be revolutionary, but in my 20+ years of experience (on both the design and code sides)…

paragraphs.text: This could be revolutionary, but in my 20+ years of experience (on both the design and code sides), the developers don’t want to worry about the bi-directional update path of both design and code affecting the same assets. In other words, once the visual language is established with a baseline version of the app/web pages, subsequent changes are best…
paragraphs.name: 2c45
